subject: Programming
title: Linked Lists
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Linked Lists.

hook.text: A linked list is a chain of nodes. Each node holds data and a pointer to the next one.

buildup.text: Unlike arrays, linked lists don't need contiguous memory. Nodes can live anywhere in memory.

discovery.text: Inserting or deleting in the middle is fast â€” just redirect the pointers. No shifting required.

twist.text: Finding an element requires walking the chain one node at a time. No jumping to the middle.

climax.text: Arrays win for random access. Linked lists win for frequent insertions. The problem dictates the choice.

punchline.text: A chain of pointers trades access speed for flexibility.

quiz.question: What advantage do linked lists have over arrays?
options: Fast insertion and deletion in the middle
